entry.title: re:MARS 2022
entry.summary: Michael Jeronimo's presentation on Space ROS at re:MARs 2022.
entry.content:
Open space: A revolution in robots for space exploration

This presentation from re:MARS 2022 provides a bit of history of space robotics and an overview of progress to date for Space ROS and plans for the future.

entry.title: Space Robots
entry.summary: A Digital Trends tour of space robots.
entry.content:
TODO: Some Title

A tour of some of the coolest space robots weâ€™ve put into orbit, and explain how robots, not humans, will be the primary explorers of the final frontier.

entry.title: PickNik wins Contracts
entry.summary: PickNik Robotics wins Space Force, NASA contracts
entry.content:
PickNik Robotics wins Space Force, NASA contracts

PickNik Robotics announced that it recently won two contracts, a SpaceWERX contract to work on robotics for the U.S. Space Force and a NASA Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I contract, as well as a Colorado Advanced Industries Accelerator (AIA) grant for space robotics.

https://www.therobotreport.com/picknik-robotics-wins-space-force-nasa-contracts/

entry.title: NASA's VIPER Lunar Rover Project
entry.summary: NASA is developing the VIPER lunar rover.
entry.content:
NASA's VIPER Lunar Rover Project

In 2023, NASA will launch VIPER (Volatiles Investigating Polar Exploration Rover), which will trek across the surface of the moon and hunt for water ice that could one day be used to make rocket fuel. The rover will be armed with the best instruments and tools that NASA can come up with: wheels that can spin properly on lunar soil, a drill thatâ€™s able to dig into extraterrestrial geology, hardware that can survive 14 days of a lunar night when temperatures sink to Ë—173 Â°C.

But while much of VIPER is one of a kind, custom-made for the mission, much of the software that itâ€™s running is open-source, meaning itâ€™s available for use, modification, and distribution by anyone for any purpose. If itâ€™s successful, the mission may be about more than just laying the groundwork for a future lunar colonyâ€”it may also be an inflection point that causes the space industry to think differently about how it develops and operates robots.

https://www.technologyreview.com/2021/04/12/1022420/nasa-lunar-rover-viper-open-source-software
